title: How to write a capital J in cursive - Quora

response.answer_text: Cursive “J” is part of what I call the KaZAKHI Family, a series of similarly-shaped capital letters. Lowercase “j” is part of the “Jupiter” family:  The letter shapes include what we call plein and délié strokes. Plein strokes are thick downstrokes made by holding the pen (a fountain pen with a square nib or a marker) at a 45 degree angle, and délié strokes are their thinner partners.  This style of writing is taught in French and other European schools starting in kindergarten (many French people are uncomfortable with crude American-style print writing). The stroke diagrams above are taken from a book I have composed in reponse to a similar Quora question (soon ready for publication). Related: Robert Matthews (馬學進)'s answer to What is a good reason to use cursive outside of signing documents?
